items.content_html: Learn sections have an "In this module" section listing all their modules. That creates a flaw for the current module, which is self linking. This turns the link for the current doc to a strong markup for the Javascript building blocks docs.
items.title: Fix up self links in javascript building blocks

items.content_html:
Fixes #4837

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/WebSockets_API lists a bunch of popular frameworks etc for supporting WebSockets. This adds Channels, which is a library that can be used for WebSocket support (and other protocols) on Django.

Also fixes flaws.
items.title: Websockets API: Add Django channels and fix flaws

items.content_html:

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

I don't think it's intentional to have a different file to download when you provide a fallback to the audio element. I guess it would be less confusing to show that the same file can be downloaded (and avoid extra work from the author side).

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/HTML/Element/audio#usage_notes
items.title: Less confusing fallback example for the audio tag

items.content_html:

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)
In the section "The downsides of async/await", it recommends a pattern of using async/await with promises. However, this pattern could lead to an unhandled promise rejection, as explained in Issue #1445. It's not recommended to use this pattern, as explained in the link to stackoverflow provided on Issue #1445.

MDN URL of main page changed
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/JavaScript/Asynchronous/Async_await
Issue number (if there is an associated issue)
Fixes #1445
Anything else that could help us review it
I change the title "The downsides of async/await" to "A remark when rewritting code using async/await". I also modified the examples, adding a rejected promise, so that the readers could see immediately in the console that there's an unhandled error. I gave a fix using Promise.all() and add a link to use Promise.allSettled() in case one wants to wait for all promises to settle.
items.title: add a warning and fix the example using Promise.all()

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

The current return link at the end of the page BookInstance Detail page and challenge points to the top of the Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page. If readers are at the end of BookInstance Detail page and challenge page, it means that they've finished the tutorial and the backlink they are expecting is Summary section of Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page.

By updating the link at the end of the BookInstance tutorial page to directly point to the Summary section (the section which is followed just after the BookInstance tutorial) in Express Tutorial Part 5: Displaying library data page, it better suits to a reader's expectations.

MDN URL of main page changed: https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn/Server-side/Express_Nodejs/Displaying_data/BookInstance_detail_page_and_challenge

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it
items.title: Updated return link to point to Summary

items.content_html:
What was wrong/why is this fix needed? (quick summary only)

wss: (WebSocket secure) isn't included in the list of allowed schemes for CSP sources. However this scheme can be used in CSP directives for Web Extensions.

MDN URL of main page changed

https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Mozilla/Add-ons/WebExtensions/manifest.json/content_security_policy

Issue number (if there is an associated issue)

Anything else that could help us review it

This scheme only works in chromium-based browsers and Firefox. So I've opened up another PR to have a browser compatibility note added here: mdn/browser-compat-data#10373
items.title: Add wss to permitted schemes for Web Extensions CSP sources
